key_title: Key to the genera of Rhamnaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Walsh, N.G.; Udovicic, F.
source.title: Rhamnaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Walsh, N.G.; Udovicic, F. (1999). Rhamnaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves alternate (if ever subopposite then spines absent)
Leaves opposite, but often reduced or absent, subtending rigid spines
Leaves densely simple- and/or stellate-pubescent at least below, or lower surface obscured by revolute margin; flowers bisexual; fruit a dry schizocarp
Lower surface of leaves glabrous or almost so beneath, clearly visible; flowers unisexual; fruit a fleshy drupe

Flowers without a tube (i.e. sepals divided to point of fusion with ovary), sepals spreading at anthesis; stamens not hooded by petals; inflorescences never surrounded by whitish floral leaves distinct from normal leaves; seeds mostly shed via a membranous 'window' on inner face of mericarps

Flowers with a distinct tube (i.e. sepals not divided to point of fusion with ovary), but if tube very short, then sepals erect at anthesis; inflorescences sometimes surrounded by distinct whitish floral leaves

Disc glabrous, inflorescence several-flowered, often a head or head-like; individual flowers subtended by a 1 or 2 bracts or apparently ebracteate; inflorescences some- times surrounded by distinct floral leaves

Disc hairy, narrowly surrounding ovary summit; inflorescences 1-(rarely 2-)flowered, each flower subtended by imbricate, spirally-arranged scarious bracts, and (usually) a leaf; inflorescences not surrounded by distinct floral leaves
Disc prominent, conspicuously indented adjacent to the stamens; tubular part of hypanthium very short; mericarps thin-walled, indehiscent; widespread

Disc obscure, lining the base of the tubular hypanthium (but tube very short in rare S. notiale), not indented adjacent to stamens; mericarps crustaceous, dehiscent by a vertical slit on the ventral face (sometimes extending to the upper dorsal surface); mallee areas only
